title: What will be China's year-on-year GDP growth rate for the second quarter of 2020?
preds: Great read on the current state of the Chinese economy: https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-economic-recovery-picks-up-more-momentum-11593502340

"Gross domestic product will expand at 1.5% in the second quarter from a year earlier, according to the median estimate of economists in a Bloomberg survey last week." https://fortune.com/2020/06/23/china-economy-recovery-2020-gdp-growth-economists/

The first quarter of 2020 was -6.8%. All other quarters back to 2017 were never less than 6% growth, with the 4th quarter of 2019 being the lowest at 6%. About an even amount of the GDP comes from the Service sector and from Industry (~45%), with the remaining coming from ag [1]. Factories are running, as are mines, but consumers in China are not spending and it looks like consumers are saving in the US as well [2]. China is considering not setting a GDP target (at 6-6.5% last year) [3], which makes me think they know it will be low. Indeed, the experts quoted by Bloomburg [3], estimate a 1.8% growth rate for the year. With these considerations in mind, I am thinking it will fall on the much lower side, and may have a year-on-year drop. [1] https://www.investopedia.com/articles/investing/103114/chinas-gdp-examined-servicesector-surge.asp
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/28/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html
[3] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-06/china-considers-dropping-numerical-gdp-growth-target-for-2020

GDP (year-over-year nominal growth) (index): 2q 2016: 181,408.2              (index = 106.8)
2q 2017: 201,950.3 (1.113) (index = 107.0)
2q 2018: 223,962.2 (1.109) (index = 106.9)
2q 2019: 242,573.8 (1.083) (index = 106.2) Normal values of q2/q1 are about 1.11. For q2 to show <4% growth would mean it would be under ~257,000. More that 5.5% would imply over ~260,800. Hm.

In Q4 2019, China's GDP growth was reported at the lowest it has ever been: 6%. Over the course of the last ten years its growth has been gently lowered from the previous 8% down to the current 6%. Although there is a clear downward trend (and as their economy reaches maturity the percentage will no doubt lower) I believe a sudden drop to 4% or less would be too much of a shock to the markets and rock faith in the Chinese economy. The narrative at the moment is centred around China's strength and their rapid tackling of COVID-19. They are increasingly seen as an authority in the handling of the outbreak and their figures indicate they have almost fully contained it. Meanwhile, the outbreak in other countries are only just beginning, sliding up the exponential curve, and are soon to overwhelm many healthcare systems. While other countries will talk of unity and hard times, I think the Chinese messaging will be more around recovery and strength amidst disaster everywhere else. (For anyone looking for the data for this question, go to this link http://data.stats.gov.cn/english/easyquery.htm?cn=B01 -- you will need to go to the LHS of the page and click on "National Accounts" and then "Indices of Gross Domestic Product (preceding year=100), Current Quarter") Note: this explanation has been copied over from my reasoning for the Q1 2020. I have adjusted the percentages slightly for Q2 as think the 4.5% - 5% is less likely in Q2 than Q1. So far, I have not been able to glean much insight from patterns in the Qs over the years.

So much unknown.  (1) What state world is in in Q2  (2) To what extent China will massage the data and (3) how much China has bounced back.       I think (3) is looking OK vs ST indicators (eg power use).  but (1) is looking much worse. So I'm back to close to Crowd as baseline.

I think this question is much more about what will politicians decide to report vs what is the actual growth rate. I find it very difficult to predict because this situation is so far outside the range of historical precedent.  In terms of actual economic reality, my view is that growth will be horrible even in a "V-shaped rebound" scenario. My estimate is that <4% actual growth is ~100% probable. 

At this point it's pretty clear that the growth in the rest of the world is going to be low. In addition to hurting the Chinese economy even further, that also provides some cover for the government to publish lower numbers: 1) they can blame it on foreigners; and 2) they can say that at least these numbers are better than everywhere else.

IMF forecasts 5.6% GDP growth for China in 2020 [1].  Q1 growth is significantly affected by the virus outbreak, with forecasts as low as 3.9%.  Q2 and the second half growth has to pick up in order to get to year-to-year growth of 5.6%.   Lombard Odier, a Swiss Private Bank provided the latest forecast for China's Q2 GDP growth. It expected a GDP growth of 6% in Q2, up from 3.9% in Q1.  While China's factories are gradually spinning up, the rest of the world has to deal with its own virus outbreak.  The growth of 6% seems to be too optimistic.  A more realistic forecast should be a higher GDP from Q2 but lower than 6%. I am drastically adjusting my forecast. HBR suggests that the worldwide GDP will drop suddenly in the event of a pandemic. But mid-long term effects will be less clear. China's economy relies on both domestic + export markets. It's domestic economy has taken a huge hit this quarter with mandatory quarantines, domestic travel bans, and severe social disruption. On the demand side, as other countries grapple with COVID 19, demand for non-essential Chinese exports will drop as well. Even if China orders factories to re-open, it will take several months to overcome logistical issues. https://hbr.org/2020/03/what-coronavirus-could-mean-for-the-global-economy?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter_daily&utm_campaign=dailyalert_activesubs&utm_content=signinnudge&referral=00563&deliveryName=DM71358

According to Xie Feng, China’s foreign affairs commissioner in Hong Kong, and the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Kristalina Georgiev, "China's economy will return to normal in the second quarter." Even if their forecasts were to fall short, Xie's statements must be China's party line. Therefore, China's second quarter growth report should be near to usual. (Not to be confused with "true.") On the other hand, what if China's leadership fears that its citizens would react badly to an obviously false GDP report?  Now I'm sorry I jumped in on this question because I now have no clue. Therefore, I am forecasting an equal probability of all outcomes. However, if China ends up posting a credible 1st quarter GDP growth number, then I will weight my answers toward the lower bins. Dateline 2-28-2020 The country is getting back to work in an orderly fashion, and people, goods and capital are moving more smoothly. Soon, the demand that has been suppressed by the epidemic will be released again. The Chinese economy will bounce back, strong. China has ample tools to make macro policy adjustments. The Chinese government has introduced supportive fiscal and financial measures, including cuts on taxes and fees, and injections of liquidity in the stock market. The purpose of those measures is to cushion key regions, industries and businesses from any shortfalls in funding, manpower or raw materials in order to ensure their efficient economic performance and stabilize expectations on financial markets. The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Kristalina Georgieva, has said that China’s economy should be expected to “return to normal in the second quarter” of 2020 as “announced policies are implemented.” -- https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/28/opinion/coronavirus-china-government.html

... Continuing. But the question isn't what the GDP growth will actually be, it's what China's government will report. The lowest annual number they have ever reported since 1993 is 6.1% which is widely perceived by economists (and chinese officials, apparently) as tending to over state GDP in downturns. So I'm going to assume that for whatever reasons there is big barrier to reporting numbers below 6 and an insurmountable hurdle to reporting numbers below around 4%.  Here's a lengthy quote from an recent NBC article: "Thomas Rawski, professor of economics and history at the University of Pittsburgh whose research is focused on the development of China’s modern economy, said it’s widely understood by economists and Chinese officials alike that provincial data is “no good.” “When things aren’t going well, and we see this on both a national and provincial level, they publish data that show things are better than they are,” he said. “Assuming the best possible effort, it’s just not easy to measure such a large economy. On top of that, there are also questions about whether there is an interest at all in actually reporting accurate numbers.” Rawski has observed China’s economic growth since before the Asian financial crisis around 1997, which is when he began to see the data run away from reality, he said. He published an article in 2001 that claimed data on manufacturing output was out of step with underlying figures on electricity consumption. “Thinking about the flu business, it is entirely the same as the GDP issues,” he said. “In both cases, there are a lot of technical issues as well as what I call veracity issues. And there’s the question of motivation of people collecting and reporting the data at all levels, and you have to ask is there an incentive to distort. I think the answer is obviously yes."

I'm aware that SARS cut "only" 0.5-1.0% off Chinese annual growth. Here's my thought process for Covid-19: 
The number of deaths is best case, likely to be 4-5x higher than SARS in china by the end of the second quarter. It could easily be much higher. That doesn't translate proportionally to an economic impact 4x higher but is indicative of magnitude. My impression from news reports is that the reaction of the Chinese government is in fact more like 10x more impactful on the economy than their actions for SARS.  So let's say that the impact is 5x higher. That's between 2.5 and 5% off GDP. I'll call it 3%. It was a sharp drop followed by a rapid rebound, but the net result for the year was -1% or so.  I would assume that the bulk of the impact will be in Q1 assuming a hopeful/best case outlook for containment of the disease in China. So I'm going to assume 2/3 in Q1 and 1/3 in Q2. That would imply a ~8% reduction in Q1 and a ~4% reduction in Q2 to get to about -3% for the year. I'll say we're starting with about a 6% baseline.  So I'm going out on a limb here with a more contractionary prediction of -2 in Q1 and +2% in Q2. I recognize that's completely off the reservation from the predictions of professional economists, but frankly they have a track record not much better than random.  (BTW: Since China is 16% of world GDP and the second-largest importer, that implies around zero growth worldwide in Q1.) Check out this article: 
https://www.economist.com/leaders/2020/02/13/how-chinas-coronavirus-epidemic-could-hurt-the-world-economy (subscription required)  Here are some quotes / factoids from the article: 
"China has slowed its advance only by severely limiting people’s movement and closing businesses. If the government were to relax these controls too hastily, progress could stall or even go into reverse" 
"Provinces accounting for more than 90% of Chinese exports have kept factories either shut or running at low capacity since January 31st, when the lunar new-year holiday was due to end" 
"Coal consumption is more than a third lower than the average for this time of year"
Property sales are down by more than 90%
Starbucks has shut half its 4,000-plus cafés in China
tourists, who spend $250bn a year on overseas travel, are staying at home
Hyundai has halted some car production in South Korea because parts are short. So has Nissan in Japan
"Facebook has stopped taking orders for its new virtual-reality headset and Nintendo has delayed shipments of new gaming devices. Foxconn, which makes smartphones for Apple and Huawei, has restarted its factories but with skeletal staffing. And these are just the brands you have heard of."
"China churns out a third of the world’s chemicals, half of its lcd screens and two-thirds of its polyester. Companies that think they are isolated from China could be in for a surprise"

I assume that the virus will be largely under control by beginning of 2Q, and will revise the forecast if that doesn't look likely.  Factories will have huge backlogs and there will be huge pressure to perform and "catch up", layered on top of what I expect will be colossal stimulus.  Also potential for Trade War to be eased as U.S. hurting itself. Downside risks to forecast are virus lingering / intensifying, and no change to Trade War. Forecast likely to be updated frequently based on Covid-19.

It looks like the outbreak in China is starting to taper off [1].  The Q2 GDP depends on when will the daily cases drop to the point that life (and productivity) comes back to normal.  Optimistically this could happen sometime in Q2.  This forecast is a modification of my forecast for Q1 [2] by shifting the third and fourth baskets a bit, for now.  Significant change will be needed if the outbreak does not taper off by the end of Q1. [1]  https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports/

This depends upon how long, and how severe, China's quarantines will be. Comparison class: Diamond Princess. Its passengers' 14 day quarantine, begun Feb. 3  is being prolonged to another 14 days beginning with the future date when they are evacuated and tested negative. The ship has been declared a high risk environment, with another 70 diagnosed today out of the 355 discovered so far. About half of the passengers have been tested so far, so the toll will undoubtedly rise. The onboard epidemic began with just one passenger, and he debarked in january only to later discover the infection. So, let's take this comparison class to illuminate today's situation in China. First of all, the impact of SARS cannot possible predict the impact of Covid-19. there are far more cases and the epidemic has caused far more quarantines. As of today, half the population of China is under some sort of lockdown. Armies of enforcers patrol the streets. In many areas, use of private cars is now forbidden. Small towns, even hamlets are cut off from each other. Almost all trade is shut down, just enough movement to keep people from starving and hospitals (we hope) supplied. How many of those high rise buildings harbor a Covid-19 carrier? Are the conditions inside these high rises similar to a cruise ship? The apartments are tiny, and we don't know whether  ventilation systems are spreading the virus. What about all the closed factories? How soon  will the virus be eliminated or at least slowed enough to open factories, resume trade? Another comparison class, each year's new seasonal flues, which attack sizable percentages of the world population. On the other hand -- Xi will lie about the GDP. He as too much at stake not to lie. So I'm mostly just forecasting by how much he will lie.  Once the 1st quarter figures come in, and some outside analyses are made public, we should get an idea of how much he is lying. Sources: 
Dateline 2-16-2020 https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/15/business/china-coronavirus-lockdown.html
Dateline 2-16-2020 https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/feb/16/coronavirus-70-more-cases-on-japan-cruise-ship-as-china-infections-pass-68000
Dateline 2-16-2019 https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20200210_32/
Dateline 2-16-2020 http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2020/02/cruise-ship-covid-19-numbers-climb-nations-evacuate-passengers

A Feb. 7-13 Reuters poll released yesterday of 40 economists based in mainland China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Europe and the United States predicts that China’s annual economic growth in the second quarter will be 5.7% (median of forecasts) [1].  [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-economy-poll/chinese-economy-clobbered-by-coronavirus-but-set-to-recover-soon-reuters-poll-idUSKBN20801H
Trump may do something to help China, hoping it will help his reelection.
Revising upward, things may still be rocky.

China's growth rate has been steadily slowly in recent years from about 7% to 6% so a continued downward trend is highly likely. That said, this downward trend has been slowing at rate and looked set to stabilise around between 5% and 6%. The Coronavirus outbreak may change that by dramatically curtailing China's potential for internal growth and frightening off investors and businesses who won't trust the volatile travel situation. Since the distrust of travel to and from China will likely continue until long after the virus has ceased to be a major concern, this situation will probably knock down China's growth rate to around 5% or slightly lower. China will no doubt quickly recover but not by the end of the second quarter.

This hinges on the outbreak being under control. If it is by end of Q1, then GDP growth will pick up but not fast enough to go back to the figure that was projected before the outbreak. It will likely be around 5%. If however the outbreak is not under control by end of March, then a drop of GDP growth will linger, limiting the figure to under 5%.
China's numbers are fudged. They will not be willing to "officially" forego more than 1% in the eyes of the world.
The impact of an extended shutdown, fueled by fake news and general mistrust of information being shared by China will see many companies moving production to either South Korea or Japan
It is hard to tell now but it will take a hit significantly. Even after shutting down most of country for two weeks, many businesses are reluctantly operating at lowest possible scale.

Q2 industrial activity and trade could rebound quickly from the Coronavirus impact as China meets domestic and global restocking demand following cooling of the trade war, in-line with trend of improving global industrial production in recent months. Meanwhile, policymakers will likely take up additional counter-cyclical measures with accommodative monetary policy and fiscal spending. We have already seen this from the Ministry of Finance. I would also expect temporary exemptions for tourism and retail-exposed business to offset consumption related weakness. Linked to my forecasts for Q1, where I currently think we will see a peak in new coronavirus cases in Feb/March, I expect sequential improvement in GDP growth due to the above-mentioned government support and reopening of factories. Therefore a 50bps improvement vs my Q1 base case of 4.5-5% growth is my base case for Q2. However, I believe the range of possible outcomes for Q2 is wider and therefore probabilities are more spread out vs my Q1 estimate.

"Assuming the virus is contained by the end of March, we revise down our 20Q1 (first quarter) GDP growth forecast considerably to 3.6 percent and the annual growth modestly to 5.3 percent," Citi analysts said in a note. Citi previously forecasted first-quarter growth of 4.8 percent and full-year growth of 5.5 percent.

Have re-posted my answer to Q1 with slightly adjusted figures predicated on the idea that the virus has not yet been controlled within China and that the impact is likely to go on longer than expected... Q1 figure could end up stronger than Q2 - if the rate at which the virus spreads has not yet flat-lined (unlikely by recent headline figures) The full impact may not be recognised through the numbers until Q2 when one could see the real drop in productivity and wider economic activity. For now the baseline is a drop of between 0.5% and 1% hit to GDP - Last Q4 in December 2019 GDP figure was 6% - matching the Q3 figure.... the New Year annual drop off in activity in some parts of the economy is now amplified due to the recent outbreak - restriction of movement from a large number of people will have an impact - the disruption to trade and other sectors within the Chinese economy that will also be badly hit in many regions across the country but I expect that to be seen coming through even more severely in the Q2 numbers - in the short term tourism and recreational economic activities (which have been growing incredibly fast) will show real declines - only caveat to the above is the Chinese govt's trusted ability to consistently manipulate all the figures to avoid causing short term panic.....
Assuming recovery occurs as supply lines are sorted and travel slowly resumes. Hattip @fisherdbus for rationale.
My best guess from projecting from past data is roughly 5.4%, but I'm hedging a bit toward reporting a higher value.
